text:
Very sad to hear of the passing Madeleine Albright

Over the past two years, I had the privilege to work with her on issues around the pandemic

She was extraordinary

Her searing brilliance was surpassed only by her warmth & humor

Rest In Peace Madam Secretary https://t.co/Z91ZRfAKRJ

So we have some work to do my friends

As much as I wish otherwise, the pandemic is not over

So letâ€™s keep our eye on the ball

Prepare for surges and variants

Work to ensure that schools, work, and other places of gathering remain safe

Vaccinate the world

And we have to continue to lead in helping the rest of the world get vaccinated, protected

Both because a global pandemic demands a global solution â€“ and because itâ€™s the right thing to do

And restoring Americaâ€™s moral leadership has been a critical part of the past 15 months

The pandemic has taken an enormous toll on us all

It has left millions of families with a hole in the fabric of their lives

It has caused so much suffering both directly from the virus and its effects on mental health, income, education losses, and much more

So, as they sayâ€¦

Some news

For all the progress weâ€™ve made in this pandemic (and there is a lot)

We still have important work to do to protect Americansâ€™ lives and well being

So when @POTUS  asked me to serve, I was honored to have the opportunity

https://t.co/qMuf6Y4wOu

Key questions Pediatricians think about?

How do risks of COVID compare to other risks kids face?

And

Do benefits of vaccines outweigh risks? 

Answer?

Risk of serious complications from COVID higher than many other diseases

And yes, vaccines prevent those complications

Pediatricians overwhelmingly recommend that kids get vaccinated against COVID

Because the evidence is clear

Kids are better off vaccinated

That's why my three kids all got vaxxed

Ignore the noise

Listen to the doctors who care for children

This piece by @Craig_A_Spencer is exactly what you'd expect from Craig Spencer

Smart, thoughtful approach to where we are in the pandemic and how to move forward

Yes, there are things individuals can do

But there are a lot of things that institutions must do https://t.co/SRtZuPwFWJ
RT @JenniferNuzzo: Wow. @Craig_A_Spencer has written some amazing pieces throughout this pandemic, but this thoughtful, nuanced, compassionâ€¦

RT @ashishkjha: With infections down more than 90% since highs just 6 weeks ago

It is tempting to decide the pandemic is over

It is notâ€¦

Bottom line is we are now at point where COVID will fade from the headlines. At least for a bit.

This is a good time to prepare for future surges/variants

More therapeutics, vaccines, tests, high quality masks are critical.

So whatever we are faced with -- we are ready

End

With infections down more than 90% since highs just 6 weeks ago

It is tempting to decide the pandemic is over

It is not

During this upcoming lull of infections (and falling deaths),

It's time to prepare for whatever is next

So what to prepare for -- and how?
